Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

colin, 
I've been thinking about the idea of mixing neuron types for a while.
One thing I would like to do is build my own implementation of NEAT ( no
better way to learn it ), with my own prefered extras, like memory
effects, and structure removal. In addition, I would like to have
interchangable neuron objects, that have different behaviour. One idea
I've been pondering is a 'neural transistor,' where an extra input lets
the network decide the activation function of that neuron. I think that
has potential to let a network latch memory's on a wide range of time
scales. I don't think it would be too easy to just patch up the existing
implementations to do this, but I could be wrong.
Anyway, I'll try the simple multiplication domain my self now, and see
how it looks.
chad 

------=_NextPart_000_C7AF_01C47D67.F54EC460
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

<HTML>
<BODY>
colin, <br>
I've been thinking about the idea of mixing neuron types for a while. One thing I would like to do is build my own implementation of NEAT ( no better way to learn it ), with my own prefered extras, like memory effects, and structure removal. In addition, I would like to have interchangable neuron objects, that have different behaviour. One idea I've been pondering is a 'neural transistor,' where an extra input lets the network decide the activation function of that neuron. I think that has potential to let a network latch memory's on a wide range of time scales. I don't think it would be too easy to just patch up the existing implementations to do this, but I could be wrong.<br>
Anyway, I'll try the simple multiplication domain my self now, and see how it looks.<br>
chad
</BODY></HTML>
